awd_titl_txt: Accelerating Searches for Beyond the Standard Model Physics and the ATLAS Pixel Detector
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide support to a single PI group working on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory near Geneva, Switzerland. The LHC machine and ATLAS, a large particle detector facility, were built as basic science tools using funds from NSF and other agencies around the world. One of their primary objectives was to find the Higgs Boson, the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts for so much of the existence of, and forces between, known particles forming the matter in the universe. This effort has been successful. The next step is to look for evidence for physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) that might, for instance, account for the presence of the mysterious "Dark Matter" that makes up so much of the mass of the universe. The LHC is currently in the midst of analyzing data from Run 2, at almost twice the energy explored earlier and with significantly increased event samples. It is possible that evidence for BSM physics could emerge at this higher energy and with the higher event statistics. Search for evidence of such physics is the goal of this project along with preparation for the next data taking period starting in late 2021.The focus of the BSM search in this award is in discovering the so-called Dark Higgs, one of the possible explanations as to why the Higgs boson has the unexpectedly low mass that it has.

There are two main thrusts of the research that will be conducted through this award. The first is developing new analysis techniques, using machine learning, to search for dark Higgs particles in the two-particle decay mode. Machine learning will be used to select out the rare events that could be the dark Higgs. The second is improvements to the CMS detector for the High Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC) upgrade. This work will improve the Pixel detector used to precisely track particles created in the LHC collisions, allowing more precise determination of BSM physics. The award  also contains an education and outreach component to engage women undergraduates pursuing STEM careers and promotes teaching, learning, and sharing of the excitement of cutting-edge research with the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview

This project advanced our understanding of the fundamental building blocks of the universe using the ATLAS detector at CERN’s Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Over four years, the team searched for new particles, improved detector technology, and developed cutting-edge machine learning tools to analyze collisions. The work addressed key questions in physics: What gives particles mass? Could hidden particles explain dark matter? Alongside scientific discoveries, the project trained the next generation of scientists and engineers, contributed to global scientific infrastructure, and shared results openly with the public. 

Key Discoveries and Intellectual Merit

1. Search for Dark Matter particles and exotic Higgs Bosons 

  • Dark Matter searches: A novel search for dark matter particles produced alongside bottom quarks tests theories involving a "dark Higgs" particle. We used advanced techniques to reconstruct high-energy particle jets and identify rare decay patterns. No evidence of dark matter was found, but the study ruled out dark Higgs masses between 30–150 GeV and mediator particles up to 4.8 TeV in energy. These results significantly constrain models that could explain the universe's dark matter content and complement ongoing searches globally.
  • Heavy Higgs Searches: Advanced searches for heavier versions of the Higgs boson using full LHC datasets, narrowing possible masses and interaction strengths for these hypothetical particles. 

2. Innovations in Detector Technology

  • Radiation-Hard AI for Particle Tracking: Machine learning models were upgraded to account for radiation damage in the ATLAS pixel detector, ensuring accurate particle tracking during future high-intensity LHC runs. 
  • Data Loss Reduction: New synchronization systems for detector electronics reduced data loss by 40%, improving the reliability of collision recordings. 
  • Quality Control for Next-Gen Detectors: Developed automated tools to test modules for the upgraded “ITk” pixel detector, ensuring its readiness for the High-Luminosity LHC (2030s). 

3. Machine Learning Breakthroughs 

  • Anomaly Detection: Pioneered AI techniques to spot unusual collision patterns that traditional methods might miss, such as semi-visible jets linked to dark matter. 
  • Quark vs. Gluon Tagging: Improved identification of collision debris from quarks (building blocks of protons) versus gluons (force carriers), a critical step for isolating rare signals. 

Broader Impacts

1. Training a Diverse STEM Workforce

  • Students & Early-Career Scientists: Mentored 3 postdocs, 3 PhD students, 4 master’s students, and 6 undergraduates. Trainees now hold positions at national labs, tech firms, and academia. 
  • undergraduate Contributions: Undergraduates led studies on AI-driven anomaly detection and presented results at national symposia, gaining hands-on experience with big-data tools. 

2. Public Engagement and Open Science

  • Snowmass 2021 Community Planning: Co-authored the flagship report guiding U.S. particle physics priorities for the next decade, emphasizing dark matter searches and collider upgrades.
  • Organized and mentored the University of Washington QuarkNet workshops, which hosted annual LHC Masterclasses and Cosmic Ray Summer Workshops over three years. These events engaged over 70 high school students and 8 teachers, providing hands-on training in particle physics, data analysis, and cosmic ray research using authentic experimental data from the Large Hadron Collider.
  • Open Access: All 16+ publications and 3 Snowmass reports are freely available via arXiv, with code and detector tools shared across the ATLAS collaboration. 

3. Strengthening Global Research Infrastructure

  • Software for ATLAS: Contributed AI-driven tracking software now integrated into the ATLAS codebase, used by 3,000+ collaborators worldwide. 
  • Detector Upgrades: Hardware improvements for the pixel detector ensured its readiness for the LHC’s

4. Cross-Disciplinary Applications

  • Machine learning frameworks developed for particle tracking have potential applications in medical imaging and quantum computing. 

Outputs

  • Publications: 4 peer-reviewed papers, including a *Physical Review Letters* study on dark matter searches. 
  • Presentations: 15+ talks and posters at major conferences (e.g., Higgs 2021, BOOST23, ICHEP 2024) and public lectures. 
  • Tools & Data: 3 software packages for particle tracking and detector calibration, plus datasets archived in the NSF Public Access Repository. 

Conclusion

This project expanded the frontiers of particle physics while fostering innovation in AI and detector technology. By probing the Higgs boson’s secrets, improving tools for future discoveries, and training a diverse STEM workforce, the work strengthened the U.S. role in global high-energy physics research. Findings and tools will continue to shape experiments at the LHC and beyond, including next-generation colliders recommended in the Snowmass report.
